segment.source: Create a rule that uses a path condition (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create a rule that uses a path condition (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals shows how to create an AppLocker rule with a path condition.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals shows how to create an AppLocker rule with a path condition.

segment.source: Create a rule that uses a path condition
segment.target: Create a rule that uses a path condition

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for IT professionals shows how to create an AppLocker rule with a path condition.
segment.target: This topic for IT professionals shows how to create an AppLocker rule with a path condition.

segment.source: The path condition identifies an app by its location in the file system of the computer or on the network.
segment.target: The path condition identifies an app by its location in the file system of the computer or on the network.

segment.source: Important: When creating a rule that uses a deny action, path conditions are less secure for preventing access to a file because a user could easily copy the file to a different location than what is specified in the rule.
segment.target: Important: When creating a rule that uses a deny action, path conditions are less secure for preventing access to a file because a user could easily copy the file to a different location than what is specified in the rule.

segment.source: Because path rules correspond to locations within the file system, you should ensure that there are no subdirectories that are writable by non-administrators.
segment.target: Because path rules correspond to locations within the file system, you should ensure that there are no subdirectories that are writable by non-administrators.

segment.source: For example, if you create a path rule for C: with the allow action, any file within C: will be allowed to run, including users' profiles.
segment.target: For example, if you create a path rule for C: with the allow action, any file within C: will be allowed to run, including users' profiles.

segment.source: For info about the path condition, see Understanding the path rule condition in AppLocker.
segment.target: For info about the path condition, see Understanding the path rule condition in AppLocker.

segment.source: You can perform this task by using the Group Policy Management Console for an AppLocker policy in a Group Policy Object (GPO) or by using the Local Security Policy snap-in for an AppLocker policy on a local computer or in a security template.
segment.target: You can perform this task by using the Group Policy Management Console for an AppLocker policy in a Group Policy Object (GPO) or by using the Local Security Policy snap-in for an AppLocker policy on a local computer or in a security template.

segment.source: For information how to use these MMC snap-ins to administer AppLocker, see Administer AppLocker.
segment.target: For information how to use these MMC snap-ins to administer AppLocker, see Administer AppLocker.

segment.source: To create a new rule with a path condition
segment.target: To create a new rule with a path condition

segment.source: Open the AppLocker console, and then click the rule collection that you want to create the rule for.
segment.target: Open the AppLocker console, and then click the rule collection that you want to create the rule for.

segment.source: On the Action menu, click Create New Rule.
segment.target: On the Action menu, click Create New Rule.

segment.source: On the Before You Begin page, click Next.
segment.target: On the Before You Begin page, click Next.

segment.source: On the Permissions page, select the action (allow or deny) and the user or group that the rule should apply to, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Permissions page, select the action (allow or deny) and the user or group that the rule should apply to, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Conditions page, select the Path rule condition, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Conditions page, select the Path rule condition, and then click Next.

segment.source: Click Browse Files to locate the targeted folder for the app.
segment.target: Click Browse Files to locate the targeted folder for the app.

segment.source: Note: When you browse to a file or folder location, the wizard automatically converts absolute file paths to use AppLocker path variables.
segment.target: Note: When you browse to a file or folder location, the wizard automatically converts absolute file paths to use AppLocker path variables.

segment.source: You may edit the path after browsing to specify an absolute path, or you may type the path directly into the Path box.
segment.target: You may edit the path after browsing to specify an absolute path, or you may type the path directly into the Path box.

segment.source: To learn more about AppLocker path variables, see Understanding the path rule condition in AppLocker.
segment.target: To learn more about AppLocker path variables, see Understanding the path rule condition in AppLocker.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: (Optional) On the Exceptions page, specify conditions by which to exclude files from being affected by the rule.
segment.target: (Optional) On the Exceptions page, specify conditions by which to exclude files from being affected by the rule.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: On the Name page, either accept the automatically generated rule name or type a new rule name, and then click Create.
segment.target: On the Name page, either accept the automatically generated rule name or type a new rule name, and then click Create.
